metadata.title: Dysphagia Assessment  Manometry
description: Manometry is a procedure that measures and records intraluminal pressures (i.e., muscle contraction or squeeze) as well as the amplitude, duration, and velocity of pressure activity within an organ(1,2)
Esophageal manometry measures the pressures within the esophagus and/or the lower esophageal sphincter (LES)(2)
Oropharyngeal manometry evaluates pressures within the pharynx and/or the upper esophageal sphincter (UES)(3)
indications: Manometry is indicated in certain patients with dysphagia or suspected dysphagia.(2,3,4) The patient’s physician will determine if the patient is an appropriate candidate for manometry
Sometimes indicated in patients with esophageal dysphagia who have complaints of heartburn, chest pain, or difficulty swallowing food or liquid(2,5,6)
Sometimes indicated in patients with abnormal X-ray  (barium swallow or upper GI series) or endoscopy tests who need further gastrointestinal workup(2)

CPT codes.91010:: esophageal motility (manometric study of the esophagus and/or gastroesophageal junction) study
CPT codes.91011:: esophageal motility (manometric study of the esophagus and/or gastroesophageal junction) study with Mecholyl or similar stimulant
CPT codes.91012:: esophageal motility (manometric study of the esophagus and/or gastroesophageal junction) study with acid perfusion studies

reimbursement: Reimbursement for this procedure will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific special agencies are applicable for this procedure Indications for procedure
contraindications precautions to test: Observe universal precautions with every patient during dysphagia assessments; take note of any additional precautions required for specific patients (i.e., airborne, droplet, or contact precautions)(16)
Manometry is associated with very few risks; however, patients might experience gagging during the procedure as well as mild soreness afterward(2)
Patients should be educated regarding these possible complications prior to the examination

indications for procedure: Dysphagia Dysphagia refers to difficulty swallowing and/or a swallowing disorder(4,8,9) Complications of dysphagia include malnutrition, dehydration, aspiration, aspiration pneumonia, and death(8,10,11) There are two main categories of dysphagia(4,9) –Oropharyngeal dysphagia(5,6,9) -Dysphagia involving the oral and/or pharyngeal phase of swallowing -Dysphagia that affects the oral phase only is referred to as oral dysphagia(12) -Dysphagia that affects the pharyngeal phase only is referred to as pharyngeal dysphagia(12) -Dysphagia that affects both oral and pharyngeal phases of the swallow is referred to as oropharyngeal dysphagia(12) -Symptoms of oropharyngeal dysphagia include choking or coughing while eating or drinking, pocketing food in the cheeks, and loss of food or liquid from the mouth while attempting to swallow(6,8) –Esophageal dysphagia(5,6,9) -Dysphagia resulting from an impairment of the esophagus or LES -Patients generally report chest pain, regurgitation, or heartburn(4,5,6,8) For detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysphagia, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic

Patients with a history of stroke, head injury, head/neck/esophageal surgery or cancer, head/neck/esophageal radiation and/or chemotherapy, or neurodegenerative disease, as well as a history of sensations of reflux, regurgitation, and/or globus (i.e., the sensation of fullness or sticking at the back of the throat), might all be appropriate candidates for manometric evaluation of swallowing function(3)

equipment: Equipment for a manometric evaluation includes a thin catheter with tiny sensors at various locations along the catheter aswell as the computer hardware and software required to transmit and analyze the information(1,2,14)
There are several different commercially available manometry devices(1)
The catheter is positioned in either the pharynx or the esophagus, and the sensors record the pressure in adjacent muscles(2)
As the muscles squeeze on the catheter, the muscle pressures are transmitted to a computer. The manometric data can thenbe analyzed with the use of specially programmed software(1,2,14)
The physician is able to evaluate these wave patterns to determine if the muscle movement is normal or abnormal(2)

The most advanced type of manometry is high-resolution  manometry (HRM) with esophageal pressure topography (EPT);HRM technology allows for one pressure sensor per centimeter from the pharynx to the stomach(15)–With HRM, computer technology is able to analyze large amounts of data and present it in real time(15)–In a study conducted in the United States with 30 subjects, researchers were able to identify pharyngeal swallowingabnormalities by analyzing patterns obtained by HRM. Researchers investigated the utility of HRM for pharyngealdysphagia due to limitations associated with frequent administration of videofluoroscopic swallow studies (VFSSs).Although a VFSS is unparalleled for its ability to identify pharyngeal phase swallowing impairments, since it exposespatients to radiation it cannot be used for frequent reassessments of swallowing ability over time. Researchers wereable to identify 12 different swallowing impairments through analysis of the HRM data; however, those types ofimpairments involving abnormalities of pressure (e.g., reduced anterior hyoid excursion, pharyngeal residue, impairedpharyngoesophageal segment opening) were identified with a higher degree of accuracy than those without clear pressurepatterns (e.g., reduce epiglottic retroflexion, delayed pharyngeal swallow initiation).(28) The same group of researchersinvestigated the use of a novel automated HRM program for evaluating pharyngeal swallow impairment and foundhigh interrater reliability within and across groups of expert users, novice users, and SLPs.(29) Novice users (a group ofundergraduate research assistants) and SLPs were given a short training sessions prior to evaluating 30 swallow studieswith the automated HRM program. The automated program produced objective, numerical data, which likely resulted inthe fast and reliable interpretation of data by new users(29)
examination preparation: The patient will receive specific instructions regarding examination preparation from his or her physician or the facility atwhich the test is being performed(2)
Generally, the patient is instructed not to have food or liquid for 8 hours before the manometry procedure(2)
The physician will advise the patient on what medications should and should not be taken before the exam(2)

contraindications precautions to examina: Observe universal precautions with every patient during dysphagia assessments; take note of any additional precautions required for specific patients (i.e., airborne, droplet, or contact precautions)(16)
Manometry is associated with very few risks; however, patients might experience gagging during the procedure as well as mild soreness afterward(2)
Patients should be educated regarding these possible complications prior to the examination

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury or etiology of illness -The first step in a manometric evaluation is gathering the patient’s medical history and reviewing his or her medical records(4) An interview with the patient and family members might be appropriate to gather a detailed history of the symptoms and presentation of the patient’s dysphagia

course of treatment.medical management: Note current and previous management of medical diagnosis (e.g., gastroesophageal reflux disease [GERD], stroke, head and neck cancer); do any of the medical treatments put the patient at elevated risk of dysphagia? Radiation therapy for head and neck, esophageal, lung, or breast cancer might result in radiation esophagitis (i.e., inflammation of the esophagus as a result of radiation therapy)(2) Current or previous ear, nose, throat, maxillofacial, cervical, or esophageal surgery/procedures might place the patient at elevated risk for dysphagia(9,17) Esophageal manometry might be included as part of a preoperative workup for patients having surgical treatment for GERD(26)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the physician has prescribed; are they being taken? Bethanechol (Urecholine) Cimetidine (Tagamet) Famotidine (Pepcid) Lansoprazole (Prevacid) Metoclopramide (Reglan) Nizatidine (Axid) Omeprazole (Prilosec) Ranitidine (Zantac)
diagnostic tests completed: Review the results of any previous tests of swallowing or esophageal function
Review neuroimaging (e.g., MRI and CT scan) results
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had physical, occupational, or speech therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors  (and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms come on or are eased) -With specific foods?(4) -When a patient has difficulty swallowing specific solid foods only, the origin of dysphagia is likely mechanical or muscular in nature(4) -Patients who report difficulty swallowing all types of solid foods and liquids should be referred to a neurologist, as neuromuscular disease is the likely cause(4) -During specific meals?(4) -As the meal progresses?
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms For patients who complain of difficulty swallowing, what exactly is the problem with swallowing?  Does food stick in the throat?(5) -If the patient reports food sticking in the throat, ask the patient to identify the portion of the throat or chest where he or she feels food sticks -Patients with esophageal dysphagia often report that food sticks at the level of the sternum(4) -Patients with GERD often report globus sensation (usually described as the feeling of a “lump in the throat”)(27) Does the patient cough or choke while eating or drinking? Is there pain associated with swallowing? -Pain with swallowing might indicate an inflammatory process(4)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables When did the symptoms of dysphagia initially present?(18) How frequently does the patient experience the symptoms of dysphagia?(18)
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Do symptoms (e.g., difficulty swallowing saliva) interfere with patient’s ability to sleep? Document number of wakings per night
history of present illness.respiratory status: Patients with a compromised respiratory status are at higher risk of complications of dysphagia(16,19) Does the patient require supplemental oxygen? Nasal cannula?(17) Does the patient have a tracheostomy tube?(17) Does the patient require ventilator support? Barriers to learning Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Does the patient have a history of either oropharyngeal or esophageal dysphagia?
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient or family/caregiver about other symptoms the patient might be experiencing, including aspiration pneumonia, heartburn, weight loss, oral or throat pain

social and occupational history.living environment: Living environment -Who does the patient live with (e.g., caregivers)?(17) -Does the patient require feeding assistance at home? -Who prepares the patient’s food? -Patients who will require an altered diet might require assistance with food preparation from family members and/or caregiver Is the patient receiving nutritional supplements orally or nonorally?(16) -Is there a feeding tube present?(16,17)

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Patients with extremely large girth might not fit into the standard examination chair; refer to gastroenterology department for specific height, weight, and girth measurement limitations
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –Esophageal manometry -The procedure generally takes 1 hour(2)  -While the patient is seated in a chair or lying on his or her side, the thin soft catheter is lubricated and then passed through the nose or mouth(1,2) -In addition to lubrication, a topical anesthetic might be used to increase the patient’s comfort(1) -The patient is instructed to swallow the catheter(2) -Upon swallowing, the tip of the catheter enters the esophagus and the technician then quickly passes it down to the appropriate level(2) -Once the catheter is inside the esophagus, the patient is instructed to swallow his or her saliva (dry swallow) and/or water(1,2) -Pressure recordings are made and the catheter is withdrawn(1,2,14) -The patient is usually able to resume regular activity, eating, and medicines immediately after the exam(2) –Oropharyngeal manometry -Manometric evaluations for the purpose of examining oropharyngeal swallowing function generally are performed simultaneously with another instrumental assessment of swallowing (e.g., MBS or FEES)(5,7,13,20) -When combined with videofluorography, a manometric swallow evaluation is termed manofluorography; however, more research is necessary to establish this as a clinically useful tool for evaluation of oropharyngeal dysphagia(21) -Multiple studies have shown that combining manometry with endoscopic evaluation of swallowing, termed mano-videoendoscopy,  can provide additional information about pharyngeal wall contraction and UES function that cannot be obtained by endoscopic evaluations in isolation. Additionally, mano-videoendoscopy  evaluations are performed without radiation, which is beneficial for repeat evaluations of swallow function(31,32) -The tip of the manometric catheter is lubricated and passed transnasally by a trained technician(13) -The tip of the catheter is fed into the hypopharynx and through the UES(13) –Manometric evaluation of oropharyngeal swallowing likely is unfamiliar to many SLPs -In the past, oropharyngeal manometry failed to become a widely used clinical tool because SLPs were not trained to perform transnasal procedures, the use of a 4.6 mm catheter for the procedure required nasal anesthetic (possibly anesthetizing the oropharynx), and the use of this type of large-bore  catheter altered temporal aspects of swallowing physiology(3,7) -In recent years, integration of manometry as a diagnostic tool for oropharyngeal dysphagia has become more common because SLPs are better trained in transnasal procedures (e.g., FEES), a much smaller (2.1 mm) catheter is available that does not require nasal anesthetic, and the smaller nasopharyngeal catheter does not appear to alter baseline swallowing function in any substantial way(3,13) -In a study conducted in the United States involving 20 healthy older adults (mean age 78.9 years), researchers examined swallowing ability by FEES with various viscosities of boluses with and without a 2.1-mm  manometric catheter present(13) -The researchers scored 545 swallows based on the Penetration-Aspiration  Scale (PAS). The presence of the manometric catheter did not increase instances of penetration or aspiration in these healthy adults(13) –Lack of normative data for normal swallowing and dysphagic populations is a considerable obstacle to widespread use of manometry for oropharyngeal dysphagia assessment(5,13) -Although manometry can be used to quantify pressures generated in the pharynx and pharyngeal musculature, manometry alone cannot identify the specific anatomical structures (i.e., tongue, palate, larynx, pharynx) generating specific pressures at any given moment during the examination(20)
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Briefly assess the patient’s cognitive function as well as his or her ability to follow directions –To successfully complete the examination, the patient must be able to follow simple directions and maintain alertness throughout –Patients who are combative or noncompliant are not good candidates for the manometry procedure

contraindications precautions: The esophagus should normally contract in a sweeping, regular pattern as food passes into the stomach; this pattern is referred to as peristalsis(2)
Additionally, the LES should remain tightly closed except when passing food from the esophagus into the stomach(2)

Dysfunction of the LES -Hypotensive LES(2,22,23) -Resting pressure < 15 mm Hg(22) -Might result in the development of GERD(2) -Hypertensive LES(22,23) -Increased resting pressure of the LES (> 40 mm Hg)(22) -Incomplete LES relaxation (residual pressure > 8 mm Hg)(22) -Might result in the development of GERD -Esophageal dysmotility(2,22,23) -Abnormal peristalsis(2) -Symptoms of esophageal dysmotility disorders include sensation of food sticking in the neck or chest, chest pain, or regurgitation -Hypomotility is associated with minimal or absent esophageal contractions measured by manometry(30) -Hypertensive peristalsis (also known as nutcracker esophagus) -Mean amplitude in the distal esophagus > 180 mm Hg(22) -Increased duration of distal esophageal contractions (mean value > 8 seconds)(22) -Diffuse esophageal spasms(2,22,23) -Simultaneous contractions with > 20% wet swallows(22) -Prolonged duration of esophageal contractions(> 8 seconds)(22) -Might result in intense pain while swallowing or eating(2) -Esophageal achalasia(2,22) -Incomplete LES relaxation (residual pressure > 8 mm Hg)(22,30) -The LES is very spastic and tight; type of esophageal achalasia determined by manometry and is based on the measurement of esophageal pressure(30) -Elevated resting pressure of the LES (> 40 mm Hg)(2,22) -Aperistalsis of the esophageal body(2,22) -Systemic sclerosis(22,23) -Loss of distal peristalsis(22,23) -Reduced LES resting pressure (< 15 mm Hg)(22) -Normal proximal esophagus(22,23) -Cricopharyngeal dysfunction(3,5,24) -Elevated UES resting pressure might result in globus(3) -Decreased UES relaxation might result in pharyngeal residue and ineffective swallowing(3,5) -Reduced posterior pharyngeal wall contraction(7)
other: Patients with a diagnosis for which this procedure is used might be at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention  instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention  strategies

Patients with the diagnosis of dysphagia might be at risk for aspiration. Swallowing precautions/feeding guidelines should be posted at bedside and caregivers, family members, and nursing staff should be educated regarding patient’s risk of aspiration ›Diagnosis/results of assessment: Following the manometry procedure, a physician will review the results of the tests. For information on the various types of therapy for dysphagia, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic. Possible findings of a manometric evaluation of swallowing include:
contraindications precautions.general: Following the manometry procedure, a physician will review the results of the tests. For

assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: A multidisciplinary approach is necessary for the successful treatment of dysphagia(25) Referral to neurologist for patients with dysphagia that results in difficulty swallowing all solid foods and liquids; also appropriate for patients with dysphagia of unknown cause, as further neurological workup might be indicated(4,25) Referral to pulmonologist for patients who appear to have poor respiratory status and/or function(25) Referral to nutrition services/dietitian for patients with poor oral intake or those at risk for malnutrition(15,25) Referral to otolaryngology if cricopharyngeal dysfunction is suspected; otolaryngologist might recommend botulinum toxin type A (Botox) injections to improve UES relaxation(3,24) Referral to physical and/or occupational therapy for patients with poor posture, difficulty sitting up in the bed or chair, or difficulty feeding themselves(25) . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program N/A N/A N/A N/A N/A . . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program N/A N/A N/A N/A N/A . See Description, Indications of procedure , and Guidelines for use of procedure , above

the desired outcome of a manometry proce: Esophageal manometry might also rule out esophageal muscle dysfunction as a cause of a patient’s swallowing difficulties

patient education: Information about manometry is available from the Mayo Clinic: https://www.mayoclinic.org/tests-procedures/esophageal-manometry/basics/definition/prc-20014211

Information for patients and families regarding swallowing disorders is available through MedlinePlus, a research database maintained by the U.S. National Library of Medicine and the U.S. National Institutes of Health, at https://medlineplus.gov/ swallowingdisorders.html Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
